SEAT OF NON-CONSTITUENCY
MEMBER OF PARLIAMENT
(Announcement by Mr Speaker)


    Mr Speaker: Order. I have to inform the House that I received a letter dated 22nd January 2001 from the Deputy Registrar of the Supreme Court stating that a Bankruptcy Order was made by the High Court on 19th January 2001 against Mr J B Jeyaretnam. On 23rd January 2001, Mr Jeyaretnam informed me that he had filed an appeal in respect of the Order. The Deputy Registrar informed the Clerk of Parliament on 7th February 2001 that the appeal by Mr Jeyaretnam was dismissed by Justice Tan Lee Meng on the said date.

Column: 1416



    Mr Jeyaretnam has written to me on 19th February 2001 that he has filed a Notice of Appeal to the Court of Appeal against the Order made on 7th February 2001. Mr Jeyaretnam also stated, and I quote:

    "I trust there will be no difficulty in my continuing to attend Parliament in accordance with the practice stated in the Constitution until the appeal has been heard and disposed of."

    I have sought the advice of the Attorney-General on the matter and he has advised that "Parliament should wait until Mr Jeyaretnam has exhausted his right of appeal to the Court of Appeal."

    Therefore, I am of the opinion that it is not appropriate for me to ask Parliament to make a determination under Article 48 of the Constitution as to whether his seat has been vacated as the Member has filed an appeal.

ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

CENTRAL PROVIDENT FUND
(Profile of ineligible members for top-up)


    1. Mr S. Iswaran asked the Minister for Manpower what is the profile of Central Provident Fund (CPF) members who were ineligible for the recent top-up in CPF accounts from the Government and whether the grace period for eligibility can be extended, particularly for the elderly.

    The Minister for Manpower (Dr Lee Boon Yang): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Central Provident Fund Top-Up Scheme was announced by Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong during his National Day Rally Speech on 20th August 2000. The top-up was given in appreciation of Singaporeans who have accepted the CPF cut to help Singapore overcome the challenges of the economic crisis. Singaporeans aged 21 years and above who have contributed at least a total of $100 to any of their CPF accounts between 1st January 1998 and 31st December 2000 are eligible for the top-up. Those who did not already meet this $100 minimum contribution requirement at the time of announcement had

Column: 1417

about 4 months to make voluntary contribution to qualify for the top-up. Of the 2.13 million Singaporeans eligible, 1.94 million (or 91%) qualified for the top-up.

    Of the 200,000 (9%) Singaporeans who did not qualify for the top-up, 69% are aged below 55, 8% are between the ages of 55 and 65, and 23% are aged 65 and above. 33% of them stay in 1- to 3-room HDB flats, in homes or are on public assistance, 27% in 4-room HDB flats and 40% in 5-room HDB flats or private housing. 55% are females. The CPF Board will conduct a sample survey to find out why these citizens did not participate in the scheme.

    The CPF Top-up Scheme has already taken into account the CPF contributions made over a generous 3-year period and 4 months was given for those who needed to make voluntary contributions to qualify to do so. There was thus sufficient time for Singaporeans to qualify for the CPF top-up. Nevertheless, the Government is prepared to consider allowing those who missed out on the first payment, a second chance to qualify for the full payment of the CPF top-up, nearer the date of the second payment.

    Mr S. Iswaran (West Coast): Sir, I welcome the gesture from the Government. May I just ask whether there would be any specific message targeted at particularly the 1- to 3-room HDB flat residents who may perhaps have not met the criteria out of ignorance or lack of capacity?

    Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, the CPF Board had actually conducted publicity targeted at encouraging all those who are eligible to participate in the scheme. In fact, since the scheme was announced, more than 600,000 direct mail packages were sent to those who had Singapore addresses to encourage them to make the co-contribution to qualify for the top-up. We have also put up advertisements in the newspapers in the four languages, radio trailers on the various radio channels, including those in Malay, Tamil, English, Mandarin, Cantonese, Hokkien and Teochew, to target at the older citizens to encourage them to come forward to participate. Of course, the CPF

Column: 1418

Newsline, a publication in the main newspapers, which informs CPF members of various changes, regularly carried details of the top-up scheme and encouraged them to come forward to participate.

    There had also been a lot of other press publicity, including human interest stories about how senior citizens came forward to participate with the help of family members. If the senior citizen does not have the $100 to make the co-payment, then the children should come forward to help him. The children should be the ones to volunteer to contribute this $100 on behalf of their aged parents so that they would qualify for the top-up from the Government.

    As I said earlier in my main answer, the CPF Board will conduct a study to find out why this group of 200,000-odd Singaporeans, despite all this publicity and encouragement, had not come forward to participate. With that information in hand, I think we will be in a better position to focus further publicity on this group to ensure that more of them will come forward in the next round.

Column: 1418

POST-SECONDARY FOREIGN STUDENTS
(Part-time work)


    2. Dr Ker Sin Tze asked the Minister for Manpower whether he will allow post-secondary foreign students to do part-time work in order to relieve the labour shortage in certain trades.

    Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, since 1st July 1994, my Ministry had allowed foreign students above 14 years of age and who are full-time matriculated or registered students of approved institutions of higher learning, post-secondary, and secondary schools to work during their vacation without having to apply for a work permit.

    Since January 1997, we have also allowed full time foreign students in our tertiary institutions to work part time without the need to apply for a work permit. The maximum hours of work should be no more than 16 hours a week and these students should first seek the

Column: 1419

permission of their tertiary institution before working. This is to ensure that their studies will not be adversely affected by their part-time work. As the number of foreign students in tertiary institutions who intend to take up part-time work is relatively small, the exemption from a work permit is not so much to help ease our tight labour market but to provide foreign students an avenue to finance part of their studies in Singapore.

    With effect from 1st February 2001, foreign students from the following tertiary institutions: La-Salle-SIA College of the Arts, the Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts, the INSEAD, Singapore, and the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business in Singapore, have also been exempted from applying for a work permit if they intend to work part-time.

Column: 1419

3G LICENCES
(Auction)


    3. Assoc. Prof. Toh See Kiat asked the Minister for Communications and Information Technology how the Government intends to conduct an auction for four 3G licences if only four or less than four bidders indicate interest, since an auction presumes that there are more bidders than licences available.

    The Minister for Communications and Information Technology (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Mr Speaker, Sir, Infocomm Development Authority (IDA) proposes to conduct a simultaneous multiple round ascending bid auction; ie, the four 3G licences will be put up for auction concurrently. If there is only one bidder for each of the four licences, IDA will allocate licences to the bidders at the reserve price, and there will be no auction.

    However, bidders may not assign identical values to the four licences because the spectrum band allocated to each licence has different technical and operational characteristics. It is possible that even if there are a total of four or fewer bidders, more than one of them

Column: 1420

may prefer a particular spectrum band. If so, the auction for that licence will proceed in order to determine the successful bidder.

    Assoc. Prof. Toh See Kiat (Aljunied): Sir, with the dampening of the 3G auction market and with the low prices that have been coming in, if not the failure of some of these auctions in other countries, and particularly in view of the very lukewarm response from the players in the field to IDA's draft auction rules, is the Government still optimistic that there will be a good response to the auction?

    Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, staff from IDA and EDB have been going round to discuss with possible bidders on their interest in coming to the Singapore market. I think we are quite confident that there will be enough bidders to make the 3G market in Singapore a successful one.

    Assoc. Prof. Toh See Kiat: Sir, what is the Minister's comment to the remarks of British Telecom that the process actually should best be a beauty contest in view of the experience that they overpaid for the licence and therefore this would have to be passed to the consumer and ultimately the consumer is going to suffer and the development of 3G may not be well done?

    Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, the comments of British Telecom's CEO should be taken in the context of the extremely high bids made for the UK's 3G licences and I am sure, having bidded for such a high price, many of them would hope that the UK government would come up with a mechanism to return part of the licence fee to them.

    Mr Simon S. C. Tay (Nominated Member): Sir, the Minister said that the Ministry officials were asking around and expected a good enough bid. Given that this is a market mechanism, there needs to be enough interest. Could the Minister indicate how many people he anticipates or hopes to come forward to bid?

    Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, whilst some of the companies have expressed interest, we will only know for sure what the actual

Column: 1421

interest will be when the final invitation for bidders to come forward is given out.

    Mr Chng Hee Kok (East Coast): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister is confident about the bidding system. Why is there a reserve price and how was the $150 million reserve price arrived at?

    Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, there is a need to have a reserve price to ensure that if there are too few bidders, we will still get a reasonable economic value for the limited spectrum that is available. The feedback from the countries that have proceeded with the auction without a reserve price or with a very low reserve price is that they regretted doing that and, on hindsight, they should have established a reserve price that reflects the economic value.

    Mr Chng Hee Kok: My question was: how was the $150 million reserve price arrived at and, at the same time, which are the countries that have this reserve price and the bid was too low?

    Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, for the reserve price, we hire a consultant firm that has experience in this sector to do a study for us on what would be a reasonable price. They gave us a range and we discounted the low-end of the range further and came up with $150 million. Members should note that the licence is for 20 years. The reserve price that we are establishing is only slightly higher than what we would be getting from a 2G licence. So for the 3G licence with a much broader spectrum that is available, we do not think we would have fetched a very high premium versus a 2G licence. What is your second question?

    Mr Chng Hee Kok: Which are the countries that have the reserve price problem?

    Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Several countries had very low reserve price. The one that had a very low reserve price was Switzerland. Switzerland started with a reserve price of US$29 million and the Netherlands started with a reserve price of US$40 million. And the final price in

Column: 1422

Switzerland was only slightly higher than the reserve price.

    Mr Chng Hee Kok: In the Minister's opinion, this does not reflect economic value. In other words, the bidder might think that was the market price.

    Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, bidders would not necessarily push up to what is the proper economic value unless there are a number of bidders. So when we have very few bidders - in the case of Italy, they only had one bidder more than the number of licences - there is really no market for them to push up to what would be a reasonable market price. I am sure they all have established in their mind what they are prepared to pay. Where they can get away with paying much lower than that, why not.

Column: 1422

HDB WET MARKETS
(Fire insurance cover for stallholders)


    4. Dr Tan Boon Wan asked the Minister for National Development, in view of the recent spate of fires in Housing and Development Board (HDB) wet markets, whether he will ask the HDB to take up fire insurance to cover (i) the loss of the personal effects of the stallholders and (ii) the cost of putting up the temporary market.

    5. Mr Noris Ong Chin Guan asked the Minister for National Development, in view of the recent fire incidents in wet markets, whether his Ministry has any plans to (i) make it a requirement for wet market stallholders to take up appropriate fire insurance policies, and (ii) provide fire-proof storage facilities inside or conveniently near the wet markets.

    The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, can I take Question Nos. 4 and 5 together.

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

    Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, there is no need for stall tenants to

Column: 1423

take up insurance to reinstate a market or hawker centre in the event of a fire. HDB or ENV, as landlord, will repair or rebuild the market or hawker centre, including the stall structures and fittings. HDB or ENV will also help affected stallholders secure alternative premises so they can continue to earn a living while the burnt market or hawker centre is being repaired or rebuilt.

    However, advisors and their grassroots organisations may decide to build a temporary market, as has happened in several cases in the last 18 months. Hence, HDB and ENV are considering buying additional insurance to cover the cost of providing such temporary markets and hawker centres. We are looking into possible co-payment arrangements with grassroots organisations.

    Sir, having said that, it would also be prudent for stallholders to take up appropriate insurance to cover loss of personal belongings in the event of a fire. While we will not make this a compulsory requirement, the Government would like to urge each and every stallholder to take up insurance coverage based on his individual circumstances, such as the value of his goods.

    Sir, on the suggestion to provide fire-proof storage facilities inside or near wet markets, there may be implementation difficulties in view of the space constraints. All the markets are old markets except for one recent new market and these markets were built to old standards and, as most of us know, the space within the wet markets is already cramped. Nevertheless, Sir, HDB and ENV will improve the fire safety provisions in wet markets by enhancing the fire fighting facilities and encouraging stallholders to practise good housekeeping.

    Dr Tan Boon Wan (Ang Mo Kio): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to ask the Senior Parliamentary Secretary whether he could ask HDB and ENV to consider paying 100% of the premium for a temporary market in view of co-sharing. The parties who are likely to co-share would be the

Column: 1424

CCC, town council, or, maybe, some other grassroots organisations. These organisations work very hard to raise money ---

    Mr Speaker: Are you asking a question?

    Dr Tan Boon Wan: Yes. Could the Ministry of the Environment and HDB consider paying 100% of the insurance premium?

    Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, HDB and the Ministry of the Environment have considered this suggestion from the grassroots organisations because we have been in contact with them. We feel that the grassroots organisations should take ownership of the markets and the market stalls. HDB's and ENV's responsibilities really are to rebuild the burnt down market. In other words, we will reinstate the burnt down market. But that would take some time, maybe one year, and in some cases, 1 1/2 to 2 years. In the interim, the stallholders are not exactly out of the loop because HDB and ENV will help them relocate to vacant stalls in the vicinity. Any stall that is vacant, we will give them. So HDB and ENV will help them to this extent.

    HDB and ENV have considered the appeal that they need to earn a living in situ, in other words, their customers are there, they need to be there. After a long process of consultation, we are considering buying additional insurance to build a temporary market, very close to the burnt down market for a short period of time. And that burnt down market will take some time to build. The cost of defraying that temporary market should rightly be borne by somebody other than the Government. But the Government will come in this round to provide a substantial co-funding and we want the grassroots organisations to take ownership of the market and provide the other part of the co-funding.

    Mr Noris Ong Chin Guan (Nominated Member): Sir, could I ask the Senior Parliamentary Secretary, if it is difficult to get shareholders to purchase insurance for products lost through fire, whether it is possible for the town council to contract with the insurance company in order to

Column: 1425

obtain the best rate and cover and, maybe, incorporate the premium in the conservancy charges that are currently levied?

    Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government cannot speak on behalf of the town councils. This is for the town councils' chairmen and the councillors to decide.

    Assoc. Prof. Toh See Kiat: Mr Speaker, Sir, can I ask the Senior Parliamentary Secretary, since the Ministry is not making insurance compulsory for the stallholders, whether the Ministry would embark on an education programme because too many stallholders feel that they have nothing to lose and therefore they do not need to insure, forgetting that they have loss of profits and business to face if they do not insure themselves?

    Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, that was what the Government did when the first market in Eunos was burnt down. Many advisors, including myself, went to visit the market and advised the stallholders to take up fire insurance to insure their personal effects. And I am glad to report that the insurance coverage rate has gone up substantially. But we have not reached 100% and certainly not in all markets.

    Dr Tan Boon Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the two fires in Ang Mo Kio GRC took place near festive seasons when the stalls were heavily stocked with the impending festive demand. I do not know if this had caused the fire. But it certainly must have made the fire worse. I would like to ask the Senior Parliamentary Secretary if he can ask HDB to look into ways to manage the storage of goods in the market and, secondly, if he can ask HDB to improve the design of the market to reduce the possibility of fire and the consequence should it occur?

    Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the Minister for the Environment, in his walkabout in the Clementi ward, has made an announcement of a market upgrading programme. The Minister will, at an appropriate time, elaborate on the plans to make markets

Column: 1426

more spacious, less fire hazard and definitely a better place to shop and eat.

    Assoc. Prof. Toh See Kiat: Mr Speaker, Sir, does the Senior Parliamentary Secretary not have this opinion that because the HDB is the landlord of many of these hawker centres and the town councils are merely managing agents, they really have no authority or power to buy insurance, or do anything to co-pay for this insurance?

    Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, we have checked with various insurance companies. The premium needed to insure for a temporary market is really quite low. It is something like between $1,000 and $2,000. So when the Government comes up with a substantial amount of co-payment, grassroots organisations should be able to afford the other half of the co-payment.

    Mr R. Sinnakaruppan (Kreta Ayer-Tanglin): I would like to ask the Senior Parliamentary Secretary why HDB does not provide a fire sprinkler system, especially for single-storey wet markets?

    Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, these markets were designed in the 60s and 70s. We have not been building markets in the last 10 years and these were old design standards. In the new design standards, under the upgrading programme, we would certainly incorporate all these fire fighting features. But still within each market, we have made sure that there are enough facilities to fight small fires. We have provided enough fire extinguishers; we have organised civil defence campaigns; we have suggested to grassroots leaders to go round the market and advise them. In many markets, like in my market in Tiong Bahru, the committee hires a security guard to patrol the market day and night. So that is something the market committee and the grassroots organisations should do. HDB and ENV will provide assistance where it is needed.

WRITTEN ANSWER TO QUESTION

GOVERNMENT-LINKED COMPANIES



    1. Dr Jennifer Lee asked the Prime Minister (a) how is the search for members of statutory boards and boards of Government-linked Companies (GLCs) conducted; (b) what are the criteria and guidelines for the selection of these board members; and (c) what are the numbers of men and of women on these boards.

    Mr Goh Chok Tong:

    A statutory board or GLC, in consultation with their respective parent Ministry or holding company, first identifies their requirements and the broad selection criteria for Board members. Based upon this, potential candidates from both the private and public sectors are then identified and approached. For public officers, inputs of the Public Service Division (PSD) are sought.

    The criteria used for searching for members of statutory boards and GLCs are determined by the vision of the organisation, the nature of business, and the leadership role demanded from the Board. Potential nominees are selected based upon their relevant knowledge and skills, and their ability to contribute. In addition, we take into account other factors, for example, ensuring that there is no conflict of interest.

    The Ministry concerned, or the GLC or its holding company, as the case may be, also seeks to achieve a fair representation of candidates from the public and private sectors, as well as ensure that the interests of major shareholder are adequately represented.

    As of 15th February 2001, there are a total of 2,175 directorship positions on GLCs (including statutory board companies), of which 176 (8%) positions are held by females while 1999 (92%) positions are held by males. As for statutory boards, there are 666 board positions, of which 54 (8%) are held by females while 612 (92%) are held by males.
